column1: Catonsville is a census-designated place (CDP) in Baltimore County
column2: Maryland
column4: 567 at the 2010 census. The community lies to the west of Baltimore along the city's border. Catonsville contains the majority of the University of Maryland

column1: Before European colonists settled in present-day Catonsville
column2: the area was occupied by the Piscataway tribe
column3: or the Susquehannocks.The first European settlement in present-day Catonsville was Johnnycake Town
column4: settled in 1729. It was named after its tavern
column5: popular for baking and selling johnnycakes to travelers every morning. It was known for being a stopping place for travelers
column6: where they would rest their horses.Rolling Road was used to transport tobacco south from plantations to the Patapsco River on horse-drawn wagons.

column2: the Ellicott family built the Frederick Turnpike to transport goods from their flour mill
column4: to the Baltimore harbor. Charles Carroll
column5: the last surviving signer of the Declaration of Independence at the time
column6: owned the land around the then newly built road. He instructed his son-in-law
column8: to develop the area along the road. Caton and his wife
column11: constructed on the Frederick Turnpike in 1787.

column1: Caton gave his name to the community and called it “Catonville”
column2: although the name was changed to “Catonsville” in the 1830s. Businesses were built along the Frederick Turnpike for travelers traveling from Ellicott City to Baltimore. The Naturally
column3: Catonsville served as a layover stop for travelers
column4: and the town increasingly grew and developed. The pleasant surroundings attracted wealthy Baltimorean merchants
column5: who built large Victorian and colonial summer homes there to escape Baltimore's summer heat.

column2: horsecar services connected Catonsville to Baltimore
column4: the Catonsville Short Line railroad was built
column5: providing 8 roundtrip trains to Baltimore daily. This allowed residents to commute to work in Baltimore. Commuter traffic exploded in the 1890s with the construction of electric streetcar lines and fancy housing developments. Catonsville had become one of the first commuter suburbs in the United States. Baltimore had tried to annex Catonsville
column6: although their attempts have all been failures. Their last attempt was in 1918.

column1: Homes of all sizes were constructed rapidly until the 1950s
column2: when much of land around the Frederick Turnpike had been converted into housing. A new and modern business district opened along the newly built Baltimore National Pike

column1: Catonsville was briefly made famous during the 1968 protest by the "Catonsville Nine"
column2: during which draft records were burned by Catholic anti-war activists.
the Maryland legislature issued a proclamation declaring Catonsville to be "Music City
column4: because of the concentration of musical retail stores
column5: venues and educational facilities in the area. Life Sounds Great is a series of compilation albums highlighting Catonsville musicians.

column2: Money' magazine ranked Catonsville the 49th best place to live in the United States and the third best in Maryland and Virginia.

column1: Catonsville is centered along Frederick Road (Maryland Route 144)
column2: formerly the main road from Baltimore leading to points west. Johnnycake Road and Academy Road form the northern and northeastern borders of Catonsville. Catonsville is bordered by Woodlawn to the north
column6: and by Ellicott City to the west.

column2: Interstate 695 (the Baltimore Beltway) services Wilkens Avenue (Maryland Route 372)
column3: Edmondson Avenue and the Baltimore National Pike (U.S. Route 40) via Exits 12
column6: with the latter two thoroughfares later converging in Baltimore City to the east. The main north-south roads in the area are Rolling Road (which is also Maryland Route 166 south of Frederick Road)

column1: Catonsville is a terminus of the Trolley Line Number 9 Trail and the Short Line Railroad Trail.
The Maryland Transit Administration provides bus service to the Catonsville area via the Purple CityLink route with service to Downtown Baltimore
column2: LocalLink routes 37 and 77
column3: and Express BusLink 150 to Columbia. MARC Train provides commuter train service at the nearby Halethorpe station in Arbutus.

column1: Major north-south routes in Catonsville include:
Interstate 695 (Baltimore Beltway) traveling south to north from Glen Burnie to Towson.
Interstate 195 (Metropolitan Boulevard) traveling east to west from southern Catonsville to BWI Airport.

Maryland Route 166 (S. Rolling Road) traveling north to south from Frederick Road to Relay. North Rolling Road continues north of Frederick Road to Old Court Road in Randallstown.Major east-west routes in Catonsville include:
Interstate 70 traveling east to west from Security Boulevard-Cooks Lane to Frederick.
U.S. Route 40 (Baltimore National Pike) east to west from Baltimore to Ellicott City.
Maryland Route 144 (Frederick Road) traveling east to west from Irvington to Ellicott City.
Maryland Route 372 (Wilkens Avenue) traveling east to west from Southwestern Boulevard to Rolling Road.
